Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Define a JSON schema for appsettings.json" (#2867) at aspnet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
As we start to write more config binders for framework components, it becomes increasingly difficult for developers to discover settings that can be set in static config files. Documentation helps, but it would be even better if we could provide intellisense in the editor. Although config can be loaded from JSON, INI, XML, environment vars, and more, our new project templates and many apps use "appsettings.json" as a convention. It would be nice to provide a JSON schema file that includes common aspnetcore settings.

**Usage**
Users can reference a schema by adding the `$schema` property to their JSON file.
```js
{
    "$schema": "https://somethingofficial.com/appsettings.schema.json"
    // the rest of the config there
}
```


**Autocomplete**
VS Code and VS already provide autocomplete and doc tooltips for JSON schema.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2696087/36056278-e7dc7e22-0db7-11e8-9621-99a97d5d8741.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Session State Question" (#2861) at aspnet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Hi,
I would like to understand if there is any technical reason why we store all Session State as a single byte stream? Which has to be Deserialized and finally parsed to extract key value pairs for our objects stored in session state. I may be wrong or missing something here but would it not be more optimal to store our session objects individually in a in-memory cache for example? In most causes we don't need all the state stored in session all at once.

https://github.com/aspnet/Session/blob/0652fbcfa8b4b924ccb74c2c9a921ec8811b772a/src/Microsoft.AspNetCore.Session/DistributedSession.cs#L333

Many Thanks
Gareth

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "High Latency seen in IIS Logs" (#2802) at aspnet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Hey folks,

For some background: we are seeing a lot of latency when talking to Azure Storage. They've asked us to collect IIS_FailureTrace Logs to see a better picture of what might be happening.

We looked into the logs and see that there is a lot of latency during this event:

```
<Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event">
<System>
  <Provider Name="ASPNET" Guid="{AFF081FE-0247-4275-9C4E-021F3DC1DA35}"/>
  <EventID>0</EventID>
  <Version>0</Version>
  <Level>4</Level>
  <Opcode>18</Opcode>
  <Keywords>0x4</Keywords>
  <TimeCreated SystemTime="2018-01-12T10:08:32.469Z"/>
  <Correlation ActivityID="{80000189-0403-D800-B63F-84710C7967BB}"/>
  <Execution ProcessID="5980" ThreadID="3232"/>
  <Computer>RD0003FF271C0B</Computer>
</System>
<EventData>
  <Data Name="ConnID">0</Data>
  <Data Name="Context ID">{80000189-0403-D800-B63F-84710C7967BB}</Data>
</EventData>
<RenderingInfo Culture="en-US">
  <Opcode>AspNetHttpHandlerEnter</Opcode>
  <Keywords>
   <Keyword>Page</Keyword>
  </Keywords>
</RenderingInfo>
<ExtendedTracingInfo xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/trace">
  <EventGuid>{06A01367-79D3-4594-8EB3-C721603C4679}</EventGuid>
</ExtendedTracingInfo>
</Event>
```

The next thing that happens shows a timestamp where it’s created 3 seconds after the previous event which is why we believe the latency is stemming from AspNetHttpHandlerEnter:

```
<Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event">
<System>
  <Provider Name="WWW Server" Guid="{3A2A4E84-4C21-4981-AE10-3FDA0D9B0F83}"/>
  <EventID>0</EventID>
  <Version>1</Version>
  <Level>4</Level>
  <Opcode>56</Opcode>
  <Keywords>0x0</Keywords>
  <TimeCreated SystemTime="2018-01-12T10:08:35.438Z"/>
  <Correlation ActivityID="{80000189-0403-D800-B63F-84710C7967BB}"/>
  <Execution ProcessID="5980" ThreadID="3232"/>
  <Computer>RD0003FF271C0B</Computer>
</System>
<EventData>
  <Data Name="ContextId">{80000189-0403-D800-B63F-84710C7967BB}</Data>
  <Data Name="HeaderName">X-CorrelationId</Data>
  <Data Name="HeaderValue">c420c068-246b-4e89-970e-8c2d4e684d23</Data>
  <Data Name="Replace">false</Data>
</EventData>
<RenderingInfo Culture="en-US">
  <Opcode>GENERAL_SET_RESPONSE_HEADER</Opcode>
</RenderingInfo>
<ExtendedTracingInfo xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/trace">
  <EventGuid>{D42CF7EF-DE92-473E-8B6C-621EA663113A}</EventGuid>
</ExtendedTracingInfo>
</Event>
```

We’ve tried searching what that event is but we’re not able to find anything – we were wondering if you were able to help us dig into this anymore or had any thoughts on what this could be?

Attaching an example of the IIS_FailureTrace log.
[MSOSP443_FE1.zip](https://github.com/aspnet/Home/files/1644453/MSOSP443_FE1.zip)

Events.RelatedBody:
Hello, I am using Visual Studio 2017 and I get this error whenever I try to debug my app:

Reference to type 'Task' claims it is defined in 'System.Runtime', but it could not be found


Any idea please ?
Thanks

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "unable to control web.config processPath and dotnet is not working " (#2773) at aspnet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Looking for advice on a web.config/IIS deploy issue/bug.

I am deploying an  ASP.NET core 2.0 based API to an IIS 10 server on Windows Server 2016 using WebDeploy in Visual Studio 2017. It wants to create/overwrite the Web.Config settings I have with whatever Core 2.0 thinks is correct

The issue is that it forces processPath="dotnet" into the file no matter what I do, but that always gives me a 502.5 error. If I add the full path for dotnet.exe everything works fine.

Fails: 
`<aspNetCore processPath="dotnet" arguments=".\MyServer.Server.dll" stdoutLogEnabled="true" stdoutLogFile=".\logs\stdout" />`

Works:  
`<aspNetCore processPath="C:\Program Files (x86)\dotnet\dotnet.exe" arguments=".\MyServer.Server.dll" stdoutLogEnabled="true" stdoutLogFile=".\logs\stdout" />`

I have checked all my system paths and permissions but nothing seems to be wrong. This is forcing me to manually edit the web.config file every time I publish because the generated file breaks my server.

Does anyone know what is going on or how to fix this? Alternately, does anyone know how to override ASP.NET core 2.0 generation of the web.config file, specifically the processPath value?

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Include dotnet sdk 2.0.5 assemblies in the runtime package store" (#7329) at aspnet/Mvc
Events.RelatedBody:
App fails to start with the following:

  Error:
  An assembly specified in the application dependencies manifest (SampleAuction.deps.json) was
    package: 'Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Abstractions', version: '2.0.2'
    path: 'lib/netstandard2.0/Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Abstractions.dll'
  This assembly was expected to be in the local runtime store as the application was published
    aspnetcore-store-2.0.5.xml


If the Microsoft.AspNetCore.All package version is bumped down from 2.0.5 to 2.0.3, the app deploys and starts correctly. (I'm assuming the buildpack pulls down the necessary dependencies when it builds the project.)

Original topic https://github.com/cloudfoundry/dotnet-core-buildpack/issues/177

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "ApiController should not return errors as application/problem+json" (#7344) at aspnet/Mvc
Events.RelatedBody:
https://github.com/aspnet/Mvc/blob/dev/src/Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Core/Internal/ApiBehaviorOptionsSetup.cs#L39

We missed this during cleanup. We're not using problem anywhere in MVC's code, so this is wrong. Put another way... we don't assume that you want to use problem, and we don't wire it up for you.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Ability to enable API behavior globally" (#7343) at aspnet/Mvc
Events.RelatedBody:
As mentioned in https://github.com/aspnet/Home/issues/2846#issuecomment-364598277:

> Is there a way to globally enable those conventions without using attributes? If not, I'd like to request it 😝 I only ever build APIs with MVC (there's never a V 😉) and would ❤ to avoid more attributes.

I did a quick scan through the code, but couldn't see how you'd enable the conventions without adding attributes. Is this something you'd consider a PR for?

One of these "picoservices" generates a web UI using the Kestrel web server and, in theory, MVC with embedded views.

If not a bug, any thoughts on making this work would be very much appreciated!

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Add functional tests to the default embedded UI" (#1570) at aspnet/Identity
Closed pull request "Add functional tests for the default identity UI" (#1603) at aspnet/Identity
Events.RelatedBody:
Added initial functional tests for the identity UI.
* Created a website using the default UI.
* Created a functional test project.
* Created the required infrastructure to write tests in a reasonable way.
* Created an initial set of tests for:
  * Authorization.
  * Registering a new user.
  * Login with a user name and a password.
  * Enabling two factor authentication.
  * Login with user name and password + two factor authentication.
  * Login with user name and password + recovery code.
  * Login with a user and an unconfirmed email (Email confirmation required)
  * Login with a user and a confirmed email (Email confirmation required)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Add an optional [PersonalData] attribute for use in the User type." (#1621) at aspnet/Identity
Events.RelatedBody:
As part of the extensbility work, we should add some mechanism to easily attribute data which is considered personal data.  

By default we would use this for the default pocos, so the default UI can include these for personal download, and also wire them up automatically in the upcoming personal data encryption hooks.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[IdentityUI]: Consider showing a landing page that says account was successfully deleted before redirecting to the home page" (#1619) at aspnet/Identity
Events.RelatedBody: When deleting personal data succeeds, the page immediately redirects to the site root allowing no opportunity to show a success message. We should consider showing a success page (*Sorry to see you go 😦*) that redirects to the site root.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "How to get ctx.ProtocolMessage.Code ?" (#1614) at aspnet/Identity
Closed issue "[UI] 2fa: Forget this browser button is broken" (#1611) at aspnet/Identity
Events.RelatedBody:
@javiercn this was probably introduced with your extensibility changes due to the base model not having OnPost defined so clicking the button doesn't run the server side handler to clear the remember me cookie.

https://github.com/aspnet/Identity/blob/dev/src/UI/Areas/Identity/Pages/Account/Manage/TwoFactorAuthentication.cshtml.cs#L27

I thought it was a bug in the new totp/security stamp code i was working on...but it turned out the button was a placebo...click on it all you want, it never clears your remember browser since it doesn't hit the method :)

This probably is in the preview 1 templates as well.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Ensure all Streams implemented by Kestrel efficiently implement the new Span and Memory overloads" (#2310) at aspnet/KestrelHttpServer
Opened issue "Log HTTPs cert info on startup" (#2309) at aspnet/KestrelHttpServer
Events.RelatedBody:
Kestrel logs endpoint when the server starts, but doesn't log which certificates were used. Now that Kestrel endpoints and certs can be configured from a file https://github.com/aspnet/KestrelHttpServer/pull/2186, it would be nice to show console info to help users identify if their config was correctly used.

Some ideas:

From store, show friendly name

    Now listening on: https://localhost:5001
    Using server certificate: "ASP.NET Core HTTPS development certificate" from cert:\CurrentUser\My

From store, show subject

    Now listening on: https://localhost:5001
    Using server certificate: CN=localhost, cert:\CurrentUser\My

From store, include more info like thumbprint

    Now listening on: https://localhost:5001
    Using server certificate: CN=localhost, cert:\CurrentUser\My, 52A477BBEDE8DFDEB699106D5FFB8FE89F9BF790

From file

    Now listening on: https://localhost:5001
    Using server certificate: C:\dev\test\cert.pfx

Multiple certs

    Now listening on: https://localhost:5002
    Using server certificate: C:\dev\test\cert2.pfx
    Now listening on: https://localhost:5001
    Using server certificate: C:\dev\test\cert1.pfx

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Add clearer exception message to HttpResponseStream ODE" (#2305) at aspnet/KestrelHttpServer
Events.RelatedBody:
This adds a clearer message to the ObjectDisposedException thrown from HttpResponseStream, when a write is attempted after the HTTP response has ended

fixes #2299

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Add clearer exception message to FrameResponseStream ODE" (#2299) at aspnet/KestrelHttpServer
Events.RelatedBody:
A frequent issue with WebSocket usage is that the user hands the socket off to a background processor and then allows the middleware pipeline to exit. The exception they get in that case is an unpleasant and unhelpful `ObjectDisposedException` for `FrameResponseStream` (a type which the user has never encountered):

```
System.ObjectDisposedException: Cannot access a disposed object.
Object name: 'FrameResponseStream'.
```

The exception is correct, but could be made clearer. I suggest a custom message be added to the exception, something like:

```
System.ObjectDisposedException: Cannot write to the response because the response has ended.
Object name: 'FrameResponseStream'.
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Move to RazorProjectEngine." (#2051) at aspnet/Razor
Events.RelatedBody:
- Instead of using Razor/Mvc TemplateEngine use `RazorProjectEngine`. This involved changing several locations (each of which used `RazorTemplateEngine` in an entirely different way) to use the RazorProjectEngine's two Process methods.
- Changed an unused public API `VisualStudioRazorParser.TemplateEngine` to `VisualStudioRazorParser.RazorProjectEngine`.
- Ported the remainder of `RazorEngineBuilder`'s extension methods over to `RazorProjectEngineBuilder`. These were used in tests and our `RazorGenerate` tool.
- Added a few test helper methods/classes to enable simple testing of the `RazorProjectEngine`.
- Resolved several test hacks that were working around little discrepancies each of the `RazorTemplateEngine` APIs.
- Changed the template engine factory service to be a project engine factory service.

**Note:** All tests pass in Razor, still need to do the manual labor of verifying this works in MVC (once converted) and in tooling.

#1828

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Move RazorProjectEngine to use RazorProjectItem as its primary input" (#2049) at aspnet/Razor
Events.RelatedBody:
Today RazorProjectEngine allows `string` and `SourceDocument` however, the problem with allowing general `SouceDocument`s is that the `FileSystem` that the `RazorProjectEngine` is based off of can only handle certain paths based off its implementation. I.E. if the `FileSystem` is queried with absolute paths and the implementation happens to be the composite or `VirtualRazorProjectFileSystem` it'll explode. Therefore, when using `SourceDocument`s we don't know whether to pass in the source documents `FilePath` or `RelativeFilePath`. This usually shows up in not finding imports for given Razor files. In the past this was worked around because int the `RazorTemplateEngine` we used black magic to call each `RazorTemplateEngine` method in a super meticulous order with the expectation that the underlying implementations did not call into paths that they'd normally call into.

Moving the `RazorProjectEngine` to consume project items enforces the idea that a user should provide items from the file system or at least items that conform to it.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Change RazorProjectEngine to operate on RazorProjectItems." (#2050) at aspnet/Razor
Events.RelatedBody:
- Removed the `Process(string)` overload to make it extra clear that you must operate on project items. This way we also don't need to worry about the various formats of paths that can flow through the system.
- Updated tests to use the new project item format.
- Did a few formatting fixes on unrealted files.

#2049 

/cc @mkArtakMSFT

- Removed the `Process(string)` overload to make it extra clear that you must operate on project items. This way we also don't need to worry about the various formats of paths that can flow through the system.

#2049

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Move RazorProjectEngine to use RazorProjectItem as its primary input" (#2049) at aspnet/Razor
Events.RelatedBody:
Today RazorProjectEngine allows `string` and `SourceDocument` however, the problem with allowing general `SouceDocument`s is that the `FileSystem` that the `RazorProjectEngine` is based off of can only handle certain paths based off its implementation. I.E. if the `FileSystem` is queried with absolute paths and the implementation happens to be the composite or `VirtualRazorProjectFileSystem` it'll explode. Therefore, when using `SourceDocument`s we don't know whether to pass in the source documents `FilePath` or `RelativeFilePath`. This usually shows up in not finding imports for given Razor files. In the past this was worked around because int the `RazorTemplateEngine` we used black magic to call each `RazorTemplateEngine` method in a super meticulous order with the expectation that the underlying implementations did not call into paths that they'd normally call into.

Moving the `RazorProjectEngine` to consume project items enforces the idea that a user should provide items from the file system or at least items that conform to it.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Figure out the story for Design Time Builds + Microsoft.AspNetCore.Razor.Design" (#1846) at aspnet/Razor
Events.RelatedBody: We need to add a test to verify that we're not regressing design time builds with any of our targets. The best way to test this might be to run a design time build but add `/clp:PerformanceSummary` and verify that our targets don't show up.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Add a test for design time builds #1846" (#2046) at aspnet/Razor
Events.RelatedBody:
This change adds a test to verify that Razor targets don't show up in
design time builds when RazorCompileOnBuild=true

We don't want to add a significant perf cost to design time builds since
they affect project load.

Events.RelatedBody:
Hello, I'm trying to create a dynamic object and pass a template to a view, but I'm having an error that I can not understand why. Does not Razor support dynamic variables with more than level? **Controller:** ``` public IActionResult Test() { ViewBag.Obj = new { Name = "test" }; return View(); } ``` **Razor "Index.cshtml":** ```

@ViewBag.Obj.Name

``` **Error:** > RuntimeBinderException: 'object' does not contain a definition for 'Name'

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Razor SDK project build-up-to-date check is wrong" (#2048) at aspnet/Razor
Events.RelatedBody:
VS has its own "up to date" logic that doesn't take Razor scenarios into account when using `RazorCompileOnBuild=true` which will become the default in 2.1.0-preview2.

The effect of this is that a change in a .cshtml file won't mark the project as 'out of date' as hoped. You have to trigger a rebuild of all dependent projects for things to function correctly.

We need to do some project system work to make this happen.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Support solution explorer nesting in Razor SDK" (#2047) at aspnet/Razor
Events.RelatedBody:
The solution explorer nesting of files in Razor Pages scenarios isn't showing up without the web sdk. We need to figure out what we need to add for this.

**Expected**
```
  +Pages/Index.cshtml
        Pages/Index.cshtml.cs
```

**Actual**
```
  Pages/Index.cshtml
  Pages/Index.cshtml.cs
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Publish ASP.NET 5 Web Application to remote IIS " (#292) at aspnet/Tooling
Events.RelatedBody:
In Visual Studio 2015, I can successfully preview / publish to a remote IIS server with a 4.6 Web application. However, publishing fails when using an ASP.NET 5 template / web applications, it will not even provide a preview.

Is it possible to publish an ASP.NET 5 web application at the current time using Visual Studio 2015 / Publish to a remote IIS server?

If so, is there any instructions on doing this? (not for local IIS).

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Manage Bower Packages: Update button should disable upon clicking" (#1010) at aspnet/Tooling
Events.RelatedBody:
Here are the steps to reproduce in VS 2017:

1. Use the ASP.NET Core Web Application (.NET Core) project template to create a new ASP.NET Core 1.1 Web Application with No Authentication.
1. Right-click the web project in Solution Explorer, and select **Manage Bower Packages...**.
1. From the **Installed** tab, click the **Update** button for the Bootstrap package. Notice that the button doesn't disable after it's been clicked, yet the update is occurring.

This **Update** button should be disabled while the package update is in progress. Otherwise, the following command is executed each time the button is clicked: `"C:\Users\Scott Addie\AppData\Roaming\npm\Bower.cmd" install bootstrap#v4.0.0-alpha.6 --force-latest --save`.

In the screenshot below, you see what happens when I click the button 3 times in a row:

![bower_update](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10702007/23536562/5c5589f6-ff8b-11e6-8c22-7aa322a802d9.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Format on paste setting does not work in .cshtml (Razor - VS 2015)" (#914) at aspnet/Tooling
Events.RelatedBody:
When disabling format on paste for C# + HTML in the Visual Studio settings, usually code does not get formatted on paste (as expected)

In razor files, when you copy and past something like this statement:
```csharp
@Html.AttributeEncode("test")
```
it also works as intended.

However when you mark the "." (dot) and do something like cut (Ctlr+X) and paste (Ctlr+V) (or just paste), 
the html helper call gets formatted (in our case like this):
```csharp
@Html.AttributeEncode ("test")
```

This is ***unexpected and even leads to a compile failure*** (razor @ syntax does not support whitespaces)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Microsoft.DotNet.Publishing.targets breaks webdeploy zip support" (#555) at aspnet/Tooling
Events.RelatedBody:
When I create a VS build deployment template in VSTS, it tries building a project or solution with the following arguments:

```
/p:DeployOnBuild=true /p:WebPublishMethod=Package /p:PackageAsSingleFile=true /p:SkipInvalidConfigurations=true /p:PackageLocation="$(build.artifactstagingdirectory)\\"
```

After the move from DNX targets to DotNet targets, this only builds the project rather than outputting a zip file, breaking the VSTS template.

I'm having a hard time trying to figure out how to call msbuild on my xproj file to get it to build a webdeploy compatible zip package that can be deployed with `Publish-AzureWebsiteProject`.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Asp.Net project with Build platform x86 " (#522) at aspnet/Tooling
Events.RelatedBody:
Here are threads in CLI and MVC repo https://github.com/aspnet/Mvc/issues/4663 and  https://github.com/dotnet/cli/issues/3091 with no real answers. Thought it would be VS Tooling bug.

I have a asp.net project that reference a native dll via Nuget package. This native DLL is only build for x86. I've changed my project.json to set buildOptions
 "platform": "x86"

But when I build this asp.net project via visual studio, it creates "bin\Debug\net46\win7-x64" as oppose to "win7-x86". If I run the resulting ".exe" file it would crash.

I've tried to use "dotnet build -r win7-x86" and it would create the right folder "bin\Debug\net46\win7-x86" and then I can run the ".exe" file.

Still cannot test the application in x86 mode.

Then I've uninstalled Microsoft .NET Code 1.0.0 RC2 - SDK Preview 1 (x64) which was installed via "VS 2015 Tooling Preview" and installed the "x86" one, and everything seems to be working.

I think it is not right. I should be have the option to install x64 and x86 and then via that buildOption I should be able to tell dotnet how to compile. Just like MSBuild and ASP.Net projects where I set the build options from Project Properties.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Question: Typescript with ASP.NET Core RC2" (#557) at aspnet/Tooling
Events.RelatedBody:
Is it possible to compile Typescript code directly in Visual Studio 2015 using the ASP.NET Core RC2 project templates?  This used to work in RC1, but since updating to RC2 I can't get Typescript and ASP.NET Core working together simultaneously.  If I create a .NET Core project (e.g., **ASP.NET Core Web Application (.NET Core)** template), then I don't see "Typescript Build" properties page in Project Properties (the only property pages available are Application, Build, Debug).  I can create a Typescript project (e.g., **HTML Application with Typescript** template, which uses the csproj format), and Typescript works as expected, but of course I can't use .NET Core in that project.

I have confirmed that my .xproj file does include a reference to Microsoft.DotNet.Web.targets, which I understand is supposed to bring in Typescript support:

```
<Import Project="$(VSToolsPath)\DotNet.Web\Microsoft.DotNet.Web.targets"
        Condition="'$(VSToolsPath)' != ''" />
```

Is the built-in Typescript compilation no longer supported with RC2, or am I missing something somewhere?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Retiring the Microsoft.AspNetCore.SpaTemplates package (Aurelia/Knockout/Vue templates)" (#289) at aspnet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
The `Microsoft.AspNetCore.SpaTemplates` package never shipped in the .NET Core SDK, and never reached an official level of support. The ASP.NET team's development resources are finite, and we think we can deliver more valuable features to ASP.NET developers by focusing elsewhere.

So:

* The `Microsoft.DotNet.Web.Spa.ProjectTemplates` package, containing **Angular**, **React**, and **React+Redux** templates, is **not affected**. This ships in the .NET Core SDK and is officially supported. We continue to invest development effort in this package. We can put *more* time and effort into these SPA templates now the effort isn't so spread out.
* If you have an existing Aurelia/Knockout/Vue project based on our SPA templates, you're not directly affected because these templates are only used to create new projects. You can continue building and shipping your app forever. Obviously we still support and enhance the underlying ASP.NET Core APIs (such as those in JavaScriptServices) that you are using.
* The `Microsoft.AspNetCore.SpaTemplates` package, containing Aurelia, Knockout, and Vue templates, continues to be available, but we'll no longer update it or work on issues related to it.
* We encourage enthusiastic community members to [ship your own `dotnet new` templates](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/tools/custom-templates). The `dotnet new` system is extensible for this exact reason. If you want to own the go-to Aurelia/Knockout/Vue project template, now's your chance! You could [fork the ones from `Microsoft.AspNetCore.SpaTemplates`](https://github.com/aspnet/templating/tree/dev/src/Microsoft.AspNetCore.SpaTemplates), or start from scratch depending on what you prefer.
* In the long term, if another JavaScript SPA framework becomes dominant, we will of course consider adding a template for it to the SDK templates package.

I know this will be irritating to some people, especially those who have worked on PRs for the Aurelia/Knockout/Vue templates. I'm sorry about that! I hope you can understand that our goal is to offer the overall maximum benefit for ASP.NET developers based on the resources available.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "ASP.NET Core 2.1 " (#288) at aspnet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
*This is high-level only and doesn't include all issues, bugs, etc. from every repo, just intended to give a general idea of release scope and direction.*

The following high-level features are planned for the ASP.NET Core 2.1 release:
- **SignalR** - Real-time web framework on ASP.NET Core (https://github.com/aspnet/SignalR/issues/394)
- **HTTPS** - On by default and easy to configure (https://github.com/aspnet/Home/issues/2308)
- **GDPR compliance** - Templates updated with new privacy features (https://github.com/aspnet/Security/issues/1561, https://github.com/aspnet/Identity/issues/1341)
- **Web API conventions** - Rich Swagger support without attributes (https://github.com/aspnet/Mvc/issues/6870, https://github.com/aspnet/Mvc/issues/6784)
- **IHttpClientFactory** - HttpClient as a service, handle cross-cutting concerns like caching, retry logic, timeouts and circuit breakers (https://github.com/aspnet/HttpClientFactory/issues/42)
- **ASP.NET Core Module in-proc hosting** - 6x the throughput on IIS! Better startup error handling (https://github.com/aspnet/AspNetCoreModule/issues/265)
- **Razor pages improvements** - Support for areas, ~/Pages/Shared (https://github.com/aspnet/Mvc/issues/6926, https://github.com/aspnet/Mvc/issues/7193)
- **MVC functional test fixture** - Easily test your MVC apps end-to-end (https://github.com/aspnet/Mvc/issues/6233)
- **Build-time Razor** - Compile Razor pages and views as part of your build, improved startup performance (https://github.com/aspnet/Razor/issues/1809)
- **UI as a library** - Package Razor pages and views as reusable libraries (https://github.com/aspnet/Razor/issues/1809)
- **Identity UI package and scaffolder** - Add identity to any application (https://github.com/aspnet/Home/issues/2311)
- **WebHooks** - Handle WebHook notifications from ASP.NET Core apps (https://github.com/aspnet/WebHooks/issues/5)

For more details on each of these features see the [ASP.NET Core 2.1 roadmap](https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/webdev/2018/02/02/asp-net-core-2-1-roadmap/) post on the ASP.NET team blog.

Discussion for this issue is at aspnet/Home#2846

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Introduction of new meta-package "Microsoft.AspNetCore.App"" (#287) at aspnet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
## Overview
ASP.NET Core 2.1 will introduce a new meta-package for use by applications: *Microsoft.AspNetCore.App*. Additionally, new projects created that target 2.1 will use this meta-package by default, rather than the existing meta-package *Microsoft.AspNetCore.All*.

The new meta-package differs from the existing meta-package in that it reduces the number of dependencies of packages not owned or supported by the ASP.NET or .NET teams to just those deemed necessary to ensure the major frameworks features function. The full list of packages being removed compared to *Microsoft.AspNetCore.All* can be seen below.

The existing *Microsoft.AspNetCore.All* meta-package will continue to be made available throughout the 2.x lifecycle, and it now depends on *Microsoft.AspNetCore.App*, but we recommend customers move to the new *Microsoft.AspNetCore.App* meta-pacakge and then add individual references to any of the removed packages if their app requires it.

## Package references not in "Microsoft.AspNetCore.App", compared to "Microsoft.AspNetCore.All"
The following packages are direct dependencies of *Microsoft.AspNetCore.All* but **not** of *Microsoft.AspNetCore.App*. Note that any dependencies of these packages that otherwise aren't dependencies of *Microsoft.AspNetCore.App* will now **not** be included implicitly, e.g. *StackExchange.Redis* as a dependency of *Microsoft.Extensions.Caching.Redis*, *Microsoft.ApplicationInsights* as a dependency of *Microsoft.AspNetCore.ApplicationInsights.HostingStartup*:
- Microsoft.Data.Sqlite
- Microsoft.Data.Sqlite.Core
- Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.Sqlite
- Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.Sqlite.Core
- Microsoft.Extensions.Caching.Redis
- Microsoft.AspNetCore.DataProtection.AzureStorage
- Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.AzureKeyVault
- Microsoft.AspNetCore.DataProtection.AzureKeyVault
- Microsoft.AspNetCore.Identity.Service.AzureKeyVault
- Microsoft.AspNetCore.AzureKeyVault.HostingStartup
- Microsoft.AspNetCore.ApplicationInsights.HostingStartup

When moving from *Microsoft.AspNetCore.All* to *Microsoft.AspNetCore.App*, if your application uses any APIs from the above packages, or packages brought in by those packages, you'll now need to add references to those packages in your project manually.
